info.game_comments:
1997 Power Players Week game 2.
From DAR Constitution Hall in Washington, D.C.

(1, 1).clue: This former CBS anchorman is affectionately known as "Uncle Walter"

(2, 1).clue: A little birdie told us an eagle is a score this many under par on one hole

(3, 1).clue: Each time a rattlesnake does this, its rattle gets a little bigger

(4, 1).clue: Shrapnel from a 1916 munitions storage plant explosion in Jersey City, NJ damaged this famous statue

(5, 1).clue: In both commercial & home property, the most important element is said to be this, this, this

(6, 1).clue: If you have one of these, you're great at making plants grow

(1, 2).clue: Marilyn Tucker married this fellow Indiana Univ. law student after a whirlwind 10-week courtship

(2, 2).clue: He played in 2,130 consecutive games; no wonder he was the pride of the Yankees

(3, 2).clue: These fluids are classified into 2 major groups: neurotoxic & hemotoxic

(4, 2).clue: Frances Perkins was trying to improve working conditions in these in the 1910s, Kathie Lee in the '90s

(5, 2).clue: From the Latin for "fair", it's a property's fair market value minus outstanding debt

(6, 2).clue: In 1973's top single, Tony Orlando and Dawn sing of tying this "Around the old oak tree"

(1, 3).clue: He played a cab driver obsessed with government cover-ups in "Conspiracy Theory"

(2, 3).clue: Prior to making Astros out of themselves, the Houston team thought they were "big shots" with this name

(3, 3).clue: This snake, subject of a 1997 film, is the largest in the Western Hemisphere

(4, 3).clue: The U.S. made this great buy from France in 1803 & would have been happy with just New Orleans

(6, 3).clue: The herbicide used in the Vietnam War used to defoliate jungle areas

(1, 4).clue: Congressman heard here, years before he entered politics:Babe, I got you babe...

(2, 4).clue: This Milwaukee NBA team moved to St. Louis in 1955 & then to Atlanta in 1968

(3, 4).clue: The Naja Haje or Egyptian cobra is commonly known by this 3-letter name

(4, 4).clue: If this act hadn't passed July 14, 1798, we would have had just the Alien Acts

(6, 4).clue: The prize-winning pig in "State Fair", or a lad painted by Gainsborough

(1, 5).clue: This woman who married a Beatle attended elementary school with Emperor Akihito

(2, 5).clue: This steel-driving thoroughbred retired in 1985 with career earnings of over $6.5 million

(3, 5).clue: This snake's French name is from its head's resemblance to the tip of a knight's weapon

(4, 5).clue: In 1844 John C. Fremont crossed the Sierra Nevada & this John C. became Secretary of State

(6, 5).clue: Nickname of oil field firefighter Paul Adair

(1, 1).clue: When she's presented, a deb makes this knee-bending gesture to society, from the French word for "court"

(2, 1).clue: Mining firm Bre-X' recent claims of an Indonesian lode of this metal proved mostly glitter

(3, 1).clue: Mom could reduce the risk of this, including salmonella, by not thawing her chicken at room temperature

(4, 1).clue: On CBS, David Letterman hosts the "Late Show", & this man hosts "The Late Late Show"

(5, 1).clue: A line in Rabelais' "Gargantua and Pantagruel" says to "strike" under this condition

(6, 1).clue: Alex Haley described this 1976 work as "faction": part fact, part fiction

(1, 2).clue: The young lady making an evening debut usually wears this color dress, as she eventually will down the aisle

(2, 2).clue: Type of illegal "trading" that took Ivan Boesky from the heights of Wall Street to a $100 million penalty

(3, 2).clue: Mom often forgets to put the lid on this appliance & gets fruit smoothies all over her walls

(4, 2).clue: This CNN "ruler" used to do color commentary on Miami Dolphin broadcasts

(5, 2).clue: Small cinnamon-flavored candy, or slang for ballpark franks

(6, 2).clue: When exorcising on your Scaremaster, you might want to read "The Shining" by this author

(1, 3).clue: Uncomfortable in a corset, Mary Phelps Jacob invented this garment at a debutante ball using 2 hankies

(2, 3).clue: Christie's must have laughed in 1997 as 2 workers at this auction house were suspended for smuggling

(3, 3).clue: Mom's lasagna turns out a little too crisp because she doesn't boil these before baking

(4, 3).clue: Baba in the 1983 film "D.C. Cab", he now takes guests on a "Politically Incorrect" ride

(5, 3).clue: For this 1959 film, a female impersonator taught actors Jack Lemmon & Tony Curtis how to be girls

(6, 3).clue: A "Swift" read at about 300 pages, this 1726 novel sets sail to Laputa & Lilliput

(1, 4).clue: This term for a formal debutante ball comes from a French word for petticoat

(2, 4).clue: A complaint by Newt Gingrich about outside income led to this House speaker's 1989 resignation

(3, 4).clue: Mom can't keep the sponge kind of this dessert from falling

(4, 4).clue: He's not acting; this man seen here really is a talk show host:

(5, 4).clue: Recorded in 1979 by Donna Summer, it's the "hot"test hit to reach No. 1, with a 3-week stay at the top

(6, 4).clue: In April 1986 Larry McMurtry won a Pulitzer Prize for this western novel

(1, 5).clue: This league was founded in 1901 by 2 debutantes eager to display social responsibility

(2, 5).clue: The scandals of his presidency began in 1923 with skimming by Veterans Bureau head Charles Forbes

(3, 5).clue: Mom shouldn't call the strips of flounder she cuts by this name; she rarely gets all the bones out

(4, 5).clue: Over 30 years, he's gone from San Diego, to L.A., to St. Louis, back to L.A., then to NYC, where he's "Live!"

(6, 5).clue: The city Armistead Maupin did "Tales", "More Tales" & "Further Tales" about

(0, 0).clue: In 1971 the eagle replaced this animal on the flag of the U.S. Postal Service
